author: potuz
content:
<@329594653097721856> I asked around and couldn't get any technical information on the Constantinople fork bug. I'm very curious by this comment of yours
> if we get rid of Ropsten, Rinkeby and Goerli, execution implementations can delete the botched Constantinople fork code

What is this code and why does it get to be deleted if we stop supporting those networks? The only wild guess I can make is that those testnets were probably forked before the bug was found and are probably still vulnerable?

author: ajsutton
content: They were forked before an issue was found so enabled the fork which never activated on mainnet, then did a second hard fork to what mainnet wound up running.  So they're no longer vulnerable and are in sync with mainnet specs, but to sync the historical chain you need this one extra fork that never deployed to mainnet.

author: potuz
content: Oh thanks! I wasn't that far off then. That comment kept driving me crazy for a couple of days. Couldn't find anything specific about Constantinople besides the delays in the media.
